earliestArticle.dc:abstract: Cilia and flagella are evolutionarily conserved structures that play various physiological roles in diverse cell types. Defects in motile cilia result in primary ciliary dyskinesia (PCD), the most prominent ciliopathy, characterized by the association of respiratory symptoms, male infertility, and, in nearly 50% of cases, situs inversus. So far, most identified disease-causing mutations involve genes encoding various ciliary components, such those belonging to the dynein arms that are essential for ciliary motion. Following a candidate-gene approach based on data from a mutant strain of the biflagellated alga Chlamydomonas reinhardtii carrying an ODA7 defect, we identified four families with a PCD phenotype characterized by the absence of both dynein arms and loss-of-function mutations in the human orthologous gene called LRRC50. Functional analyses performed in Chlamydomonas reinhardtii and in another flagellated protist, Trypanosoma brucei, support a key role for LRRC50, a member of the leucine-rich-repeat superfamily, in cytoplasmic preassembly of dynein arms.
earliestArticle.dc:creator: Duquesnoy P
earliestArticle.dc:title: Loss-of-function mutations in the human ortholog of Chlamydomonas reinhardtii ODA7 disrupt dynein arm assembly and cause primary ciliary dyskinesia.

earliestArticle.dc:abstract: Genetic defects affecting motility of cilia and flagella cause chronic destructive airway disease, randomization of left-right body asymmetry, and, frequently, male infertility in primary ciliary dyskinesia (PCD). The most frequent defects involve outer and inner dynein arms (ODAs and IDAs) that are large multiprotein complexes responsible for cilia-beat generation and regulation, respectively. Here, we demonstrate that large genomic deletions, as well as point mutations involving LRRC50, are responsible for a distinct PCD variant that is characterized by a combined defect involving assembly of the ODAs and IDAs. Functional analyses showed that LRRC50 deficiency disrupts assembly of distally and proximally DNAH5- and DNAI2-containing ODA complexes, as well as DNALI1-containing IDA complexes, resulting in immotile cilia. On the basis of these findings, we assume that LRRC50 plays a role in assembly of distinct dynein-arm complexes.
earliestArticle.dc:creator: Loges NT
earliestArticle.dc:title: Deletions and point mutations of LRRC50 cause primary ciliary dyskinesia due to dynein arm defects.

evidence.dc:description: In situ hybridization analysis of whole mouse embryos with an Lrrc50 (Dnaaf1) probe found expression in the node (early gastrulation-stage embryos) and ciliated mouse respiratory cells (naso-pharynx and nasal cavity epithelial cells).  This expression is consistent with a role for DNAAF1 in ciliary axoneme assembly in motile ciliated cells of the left-right organizer and respiratory epithelial cells of mice and humans. Patients carrying DNAAF1 mutations develop severe respiratory symptoms and can also carry laterality defects, both phenotypes associated with ciliary defects.
evidence.rdfs:label: Dnaaf1 (Lrrc50) expression in embryonic mice ciliated tissue

evidence.dc:description: The expression of LRRC50 (DNAAF1) in different human tissues was assessed by quantitative RT-PCR analysis. LRRC50 transcripts were found in highest levels in trachea followed by high levels in testis and lung.  These are tissues with multi-ciliated cells that have defective cilia in PCD patients.
evidence.rdfs:label: DNAAF1 gene expression in different human tissues

evidence.dc:description: PCD can arise from mutations in genes encoding any of an array of cytoplasmic proteins collectively known as dynein axonemal assembly factors, DNAAFs, that help pre-assemble axonemal dynein motors in the cytoplasm before deployment to cilia (PMID: 32943623). An interaction of DNAAF1 with a RUVBL1-RUVBL2 complex is consistent with a model where DNAAF1 is part of a larger cytoplasmic multi-protein complex that assembles inner and outer dynein arm components. The AAA+ ATPases RUVBL1 and RUVBL are thought to form a scaffold for complex protein-protein interactions. The structure and ATPase activity of RUVBL1-RUVBL2 can be affected and regulated by the interaction with different proteins (PMID: 33129013). While RUVBL1 and RUVBL2 have not been directly associated with human PCD, they have been associated with dysfunction of motile cilia in zebrafish and mice (PMIDs: 23858445, 29959317).

dc:source.dc:abstract: DNAAF1 (LRRC50) is a cytoplasmic protein required for dynein heavy chain assembly and cilia motility, and DNAAF1 mutations cause primary ciliary dyskinesia (PCD; MIM 613193). We describe four families with DNAAF1 mutations and complex congenital heart disease (CHD). In three families, all affected individuals have typical PCD phenotypes. However, an additional family demonstrates isolated CHD (heterotaxy) in two affected siblings, but no clinical evidence of PCD. We identified a homozygous DNAAF1 missense mutation, p.Leu191Phe, as causative for heterotaxy in this family. Genetic complementation in dnaaf1-null zebrafish embryos demonstrated the rescue of normal heart looping with wild-type human DNAAF1, but not the p.Leu191Phe variant, supporting the conserved pathogenicity of this DNAAF1 missense mutation. This observation points to a phenotypic continuum between CHD and PCD, providing new insights into the pathogenesis of isolated CHD. In further investigations of the function of DNAAF1 in dynein arm assembly, we identified interactions with members of a putative dynein arm assembly complex. These include the ciliary intraflagellar transport protein IFT88 and the AAA+â€‰(ATPases Associated with various cellular Activities) family proteins RUVBL1 (Pontin) and RUVBL2 (Reptin). Co-localization studies support these findings, with the loss of RUVBL1 perturbing the co-localization of DNAAF1 with IFT88. We show that RUVBL1 orthologues have an asymmetric left-sided distribution at both the mouse embryonic node and the Kupffer's vesicle in zebrafish embryos, with the latter asymmetry dependent on DNAAF1. These results suggest that DNAAF1-RUVBL1 biochemical and genetic interactions have a novel functional role in symmetry breaking and cardiac development.
dc:source.dc:creator: Hartill VL
dc:source.dc:title: DNAAF1 links heart laterality with the AAA+ ATPase RUVBL1 and ciliary intraflagellar transport.

evidence.rdfs:label: DNAAF1 interacts with RUVBL1 and RUVBL2

evidence.dc:description: High-resolution immunofluorescence microscopy in control and LRRC50 mutant respiratory cells from patient OP250-II1, using specific antibodies directed against various dynein-arm components showed a loss of the ODA heavy chains DNAH5 and DNAH9 and the ODA intermediate chain DNAI2 from the ciliary axonemes, indicating that loss of LRRC50 affects the assembly of proximally (type 1) and distally (type 2) located ODA complexes in respiratory cells.  DNALI1, an IDA component, was also absent from all mutant ciliary axonemes and instead accumulated in the cytoplasm. These data are consistent with DNAAF1 assisting in the cytoplasmic assembly of axonemal dyneins.
evidence.rdfs:label: Axonemal defects seen by IF in cilia of DNAAF1/PCD patient

evidence.dc:description: Zebrafish embryos carrying a homozygous dnaaf1 mutation have immotile cilia. Multiciliated cells in the zebrafish pronephros are motile and this motility is thought to be important for moving fluid through the kidney. Similarly ciliary motility in the Kupffer's vesicle plays a role in the establishment of left-right asymmetry during early embryogenesis. Impaired ciliary motility in dnaaf1 mutant embryos leads to left-right polarity defects, a deficiency in pronephric fluid flow, and the development of pronephric cysts.  Human PCD patients carrying DNAAF1 mutations similarly exhibit immotile cilia and as consequence experience respiratory symptoms, laterality defects, and infertility. Both humans and zebrafish with defective DNAAF1 show ultrastructural axonemal defects.  Human patients have absent inner and outer dynein arms.  Zebrafish mutants also are missing outer dynein arms and in some cases have missing or misplaced inner dynein arms.  These ultrastructural defects are consistent with a role for DNAAF1 in the preassembly of dynein arms in both humans and zebrafish.

dc:source.dc:abstract: Cilia perform essential motile and sensory functions central to many developmental and physiological processes. Disruption of their structure or function can have profound phenotypic consequences, and has been linked to left-right patterning and polycystic kidney disease. In a forward genetic screen for mutations affecting ciliary motility, we isolated zebrafish mutant hu255H. The mutation was found to disrupt an ortholog of the uncharacterized highly conserved human SDS22-like leucine-rich repeat(LRR)-containing protein LRRC50 (16q24.1) and Chlamydomonas Oda7p. Zebrafish lrrc50 is specifically expressed in all ciliated tissues. lrrc50(hu255H) mutants develop pronephric cysts with an increased proliferative index, severely reduced brush border, and disorganized pronephric cilia manifesting impaired localized fluid flow consistent with ciliary dysfunction. Electron microscopy analysis revealed ultrastructural irregularities of the dynein arms and misalignments of the outer-doublet microtubules on the ciliary axonemes, suggesting instability of the ciliary architecture in lrrc50(hu255H) mutants. TheSDS22-like leucine-rich repeats present in Lrrc50 are necessary for proper protein function, since injection of a deletion construct of the first LRR did not rescue the zebrafish mutant phenotype. Subcellular distribution of human LRRC50-EGFP in MDCK and HEK293T cells is diffusely cytoplasmic and concentrated at the mitotic spindle poles and cilium. LRRC50 RNAi knock-down in human proximal tubule HK-2 cells thoroughly recapitulated the zebrafish brush border and cilia phenotype, suggesting conservation of LRRC50 function between both species. In summary, we present the first genetic vertebrate model for lrrc50 function and propose LRRC50 to be a novel candidate gene for human cystic kidney disease, involved in regulation of microtubule-based cilia and actin-based brush border microvilli.
dc:source.dc:creator: van Rooijen E
dc:source.dc:title: LRRC50, a conserved ciliary protein implicated in polycystic kidney disease.

evidence.rdfs:label: Zebrafish model with dnaaf1 loss of function mutation

evidence.dc:description: Down-scored 0.5 because the PCD respiratory phenotype cannot be recapitulated in zebrafish.

While a trypanosome knockdown model does not recapitulate the respiratory, laterality or fertility defects seen in DNAAF1 PCD patients, the  trypanosome phenotypes of defective flagellar motility, the absence of outer dynein arms, and the cytoplasmic accumulation of DNAI1 are consistent with a defect in dynein arm assembly such as that seen in human patients with DNAAF1 loss of function.
evidence.rdfs:label: RNAi-induced silencing of TbODA7 in Trypanosoma brucei

evidence.dc:description: This model does not recapitulate the respiratory, laterality or fertility defects seen in DNAAF1 PCD patients.

Mice homozygous for a recessive Dnaaf1 splicing mutation exhibit phenotypes consistent with those seen in PCD patients carrying DNAAF1 mutations. Phenotypes in common include severe respiratory infection and laterality defects. Both these phenotypes are consistent with cases of ciliary defect or dysfunction.  In humans, TEM analysis shows the absence of both inner and outer dynein arms in DNAAF1 PCD patients.  Unfortunately this analysis was not done for these mice.  High-resolution immunofluorescence microscopy in control and DNAAF1 mutant respiratory cells from PCD patients, using specific antibodies directed against various dynein-arm components showed a loss of the ODA heavy chains DNAH5 and DNAH9 and the ODA intermediate chain DNAI2 from the ciliary axonemes, indicating that loss of DNAAF1 affects the assembly of proximally (type 1) and distally (type 2) located ODA complexes in respiratory cells. DNALI1, an IDA component, was also absent from all mutant ciliary axonemes and instead accumulated in the cytoplasm. These data are consistent with DNAAF1 assisting in the cytoplasmic assembly/transport of axonemal dyneins.  In mutant mice, immunofluorescent studies showed normal localization of DNAH9, a result that the authors of this study did not really explain.  While not noted by the authors, in Figure 6  Dnaaf1 mice appear to have lower levels of DNAH9 than wild type and there appears to be accumulation of DNAH9 in the cytoplasm.

dc:source.dc:abstract: We have previously described a forward genetic screen in mice for abnormalities of brain development. Characterization of two hydrocephalus mutants by whole-exome sequencing after whole-genome SNP mapping revealed novel recessive mutations in Dnaaf1 and Lrrc48 Mouse mutants of these two genes have not been previously reported. The Dnaaf1 mutant carries a mutation at the splice donor site of exon 4, which results in abnormal transcripts. The Lrrc48 mutation is a missense mutation at a highly conserved leucine residue, which is also associated with a decrease in Lrrc48 transcription. Both Dnaaf1 and Lrrc48 belong to a leucine-rich repeat-containing protein family and are components of the ciliary axoneme. Their Chlamydomonas orthologs are known to be required for normal ciliary beat frequency or flagellar waveform, respectively. Some Dnaaf1 or Lrrc48 homozygote mutants displayed laterality defects, suggesting a motile cilia defect in the embryonic node. Mucus accumulation and neutrophil infiltration in the maxillary sinuses suggested sinusitis. Dnaaf1 mutants showed postnatal lethality, and none survived to weaning age. Lrrc48 mutants survive to adulthood, but had male infertility. ARL13B immunostaining showed the presence of motile cilia in the mutants, and the distal distribution of DNAH9 in the axoneme of upper airway motile cilia appeared normal. The phenotypic abnormalities suggest that mutations in Dnaaf1 and Lrrc48 cause defects in motile cilia function.
dc:source.dc:creator: Ha S
dc:source.dc:title: Mutations in Dnaaf1 and Lrrc48 Cause Hydrocephalus, Laterality Defects, and Sinusitis in Mice.

evidence.rdfs:label: Recessive mouse Dnaaf1 mutation as PCD model

evidence.dc:description: Down-scored 0.5 because of missing or ambiguous data on axonemal ultrastructure and localization of dyneins.
Down-scored 0.5 for consanguinity. NM_178452.6(DNAAF1):c.1484del (p.Pro495GlnfsTer?) is a frameshift mutation that is predicted to trigger NMD or at least truncate ~32% of the protein product.
Down-scored 0.5 for consanguinity. NM_178452.6(DNAAF1):c.285del (p.Lys95AsnfsTer14) is a frameshift mutation that is predicted to trigger NMD or at least truncate ~87% of the protein product.

evidence.detectionMethod: Total genome scans were performed by using single-nucleotide polymorphism (SNP) arrays in seven consanguineous PCD families with combined ODA and IDA defects. LRCC50 (DNAAF1)was identified as a candidate gene (out of ~770 genes) because it was associated with cilia and flagella ultrastructural defects (ODA and IDA) in zebrafish and Chlamydomonas. PCR amplification of 12 fragments (including all exons of LRCC50) from genomic DNA identified a homozygous loss-of-function mutation.
evidence.rdfs:label: OP250-II1

evidence.dc:description: High-resolution immunofluorescence microscopy in control and LRRC50 mutant respiratory cells from patient OP250-II1, using specific antibodies directed against various dynein-arm components showed a loss of the ODA heavy chains DNAH5 and DNAH9 and the ODA intermediate chain DNAI2 from the ciliary axonemes, indicating that loss of LRRC50 affects the assembly of proximally (type 1) and distally (type 2) located ODA complexes in respiratory cells.  DNALI1, an IDA component,  was also absent from all mutant ciliary axonemes and instead accumulated in the cytoplasm. This data will not be scored for the variant but rather as experimental support for the function of DNAAF1.

NM_178452.6(DNAAF1):c.1349dup (p.Pro451AlafsTer6) is a frameshift mutation that is predicted to trigger NMD or at least truncate ~38% of the protein product. Down-scored 0.5 for homozygosity by consanguinity. Functional data 0.5 points not included in final score.

evidence.detectionMethod: Tested with a genetic panel that included at least 28 genes associated with primary ciliary dyskinesia (PCD).
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Confirmed PCD (abnormal ciliary ultrastructure by transmission electron microscopy and/or genetic mutations consistent with PCD along with compatible clinical features)

dc:source.dc:abstract: In primary ciliary dyskinesia, factors leading to disease heterogeneity are poorly understood.
dc:source.dc:creator: Davis SD
dc:source.dc:title: Primary Ciliary Dyskinesia: Longitudinal Study of Lung Disease by Ultrastructure Defect and Genotype.

evidence.rdfs:label: Davis O+IDA04

evidence.dc:description: Down-scored 0.5 for lack of parental genotyping and 0.5 for lack of information on second allele. NM_178452.6(DNAAF1):c.778C>T (p.Gln260Ter) is a nonsense mutation that is predicted to trigger NMD or at least truncate ~64% of the protein product.

evidence.detectionMethod: Whole genome sequencing and breakpoint analysis
evidence.rdfs:label: Hartill Family D-II1

evidence.dc:description: Down-scored 0.5 for homozygosity by consanguinity and 0.25 for lack of parental genotyping. NC_000016.10:g.84159561_84167498del or NM_178452.6:c.742-114_1030+1549del is a 7937bp multi exon deletion (exons 6 and 7).  This region of the gene encodes a conserved coiled-coil domain.

evidence.detectionMethod: Authors screened for LRRC50 (DNAAF1) mutations in 24 patients (12 males and 12 females, from 23 independent families) with PCD related to an absence of both dynein arms.  All patients were born to healthy parents.  When possible, parents were genotyped
evidence.rdfs:label: Duquesnoy Family D33_II1

evidence.dc:description: NM_178452.6(DNAAF1):c.115dup (p.Cys39LeufsTer6) is a frameshift mutation that is predicted to trigger NMD or at least truncate ~95% of the protein product. Down-scored 0.5 for not using a genome-wide analysis method for genotyping variant and 0.5 for lack of parental genotyping.

NM_178452.6(DNAAF1):c.1300_1322del is a frameshift mutation that is predicted to trigger NMD or at least truncate ~40% of the protein product. Down-scored 0.5 for not using a genome-wide analysis method for genotyping variant and 0.5 for lack of parental genotyping.

evidence.detectionMethod: Authors screened for LRRC50 (DNAAF1) mutations in 24 patients (12 males and 12 females, from 23 independent families) with PCD related to an absence of both dynein arms.  All patients were born to healthy parents.  When possible, parents were genotyped
evidence.rdfs:label: Duquesnoy Family D11_II1

evidence.dc:description: The p.Leu175Arg mutation replaces an apolar and neutral amino acid with a polar and charged amino acid.  In addition the Leu175 residue is highly conserved across species (Fig 2A) and is thought to be one of the leucine residues that contributes to the hydrophobic core of the LRR motif arc.  Chlamydomonas reinhardtii was used to assess the functional consequences of this missense mutation. In an oda7-1 strain, WT ODA7 rescues the strain to WT motility.  No phenotypic rescue was observed with an ODA7 protein carrying the p.Leu92Arg mutation that is orthologous to the human p.Leu175Arg mutation.

NM_178452.6(DNAAF1):c.524T>G (p.Leu175Arg) is a missense mutation that is predicted to be probably damaging by Polyphen-2. Down-scored for homozygosity by consanguinity and for not using genome-wide analysis methods to genotype patients.

evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Diffuse nodules; Inconclusive TEM ultrastructural data; PCD diagnosis confirmed in this study;  Thoracic deformity,

dc:source.dc:abstract: To report detailed knowledge about the clinical manifestations, ciliary phenotypes, genetic spectrum as well as phenotype/genotype correlation in primary ciliary dyskinesia (PCD) in Chinese children.
dc:source.dc:creator: Guo Z
dc:source.dc:title: Clinical and Genetic Spectrum of Children with Primary Ciliary Dyskinesia in China.

Down-scored 0.5 for lack of parental genotyping. NM_178452.6(DNAAF1):c.1801_1804del (p.Asp601LeufsTer?) is a frameshift mutation that is predicted to trigger NMD or at least truncate ~17% of the protein product.

evidence.detectionMethod: Authors screened for LRRC50 (DNAAF1) mutations in 24 patients (12 males and 12 females, from 23 independent families) with PCD related to an absence of both dynein arms.  All patients were born to healthy parents.  When possible, parents were genotyped
evidence.rdfs:label: Duquesnoy Family D115_II2

evidence.dc:description: NM_178452.6(DNAAF1):c.508dup (p.Glu170GlyfsTer10) is a frameshift mutation that is predicted to trigger NMD or at least truncate ~77% of the protein product. Down-scored 0.5 for not using a genome-wide analysis method for genotyping variant .

NM_178452.6(DNAAF1):c.792C>A (p.Tyr264Ter)is a nonsense mutation that is predicted to trigger NMD or at least truncate ~64% of the protein product. Down-scored 0.5 for not using a genome-wide analysis method for genotyping variant.

evidence.detectionMethod: Authors screened for LRRC50 (DNAAF1) mutations in 24 patients (12 males and 12 females, from 23 independent families) with PCD related to an absence of both dynein arms.  All patients were born to healthy parents.  When possible, parents were genotyped.
evidence.rdfs:label: Duquesnoy Family D42_II1

evidence.dc:description: NM_178452.6(DNAAF1):c.1198_1199insTCGC (p.Pro400LeufsTer6) is a frameshift mutation that is predicted to trigger NMD or at least truncate ~45% of the protein product. Down-scored 0.5 points for method of genotyping that only tested DNAAF1.

NC_000016.10:g.84147100_84152475del is a 5376bp deletion in DNAAF1 that includes the intron 1 acceptor site, exon 2, intron 2, exon 3 and the exon 3 donor site.   Were exon 2 and 3 to be simply skipped, it is predicted that this deletion would result in the deletion of p.Glu42_Lys117. Down-scored 0.5 points for lack of genome-wide genotyping methods.

evidence.detectionMethod: Tested with a genetic panel that included at least 28 genes associated with primary ciliary dyskinesia (PCD).
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Confirmed PCD (abnormal ciliary ultrastructure by transmission electron microscopy and/or genetic mutations consistent with PCD along with compatible clinical features)
evidence.rdfs:label: Davis O+IDA03

evidence.dc:description: Down scored 0.5 for homozygosity. Down-scored 0.25 for lack of parental genotyping.  NM_178452.6(DNAAF1):c.831C>G (p.Tyr277Ter) is a nonsense mutation that is predicted to trigger NMD or at least truncate ~62% of the protein product.

evidence.detectionMethod: 58 PCD families with ODA defects were tested for LRRC50 (DNAAF1) mutations by PCR amplification. This PCR analysis followed by Sanger sequencing identified a nonsense LRRC50 mutation in UNC65.  Because there was no parental DNA available for analysis, the authors were unable to determine if there was a homozygous point mutation or perhaps a heterozygous deletion. High-resolution SNP genotyping and quantitative PCR (for detection of copy-number variations) corroborated the finding of a large ~220kb deletion that affected DNAAF1 and 5 other genes.
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: PCD Diagnosis; Partial lobectomy of the left lung at age 25 because of destructive lung disease.
evidence.rdfs:label: UNC65

evidence.dc:description: NM_178452.6(DNAAF1):c.811C>T (p.Arg271Ter) is a nonsense mutation that is predicted to trigger NMD or at least truncate ~63% of the protein product. Down-scored 0.5 for consanguinity and 0.5 for genotyping method that only tested for DNAAF1. Down-scored remaining 0.5 for being in trans with large multi-gene deletion

This variant has been scored in proband Hartill Family B-II1. NM_178452.6(DNAAF1):c.1484del (p.Pro495GlnfsTer?) is a frameshift mutation that is predicted to trigger NMD or at least truncate ~32% of the protein product.

evidence.detectionMethod: Whole exome sequencing; Copy number variant analysis. Sanger sequencing to confirm that variant was homozygous in patient and heterozygous in mother. No paternal genotype was available.
evidence.phenotypeFreeText:
Normal ODA and IDA ultrastructure; Normal NO measurements; Normal range ciliary beat frequency; Sparsely ciliated nasal epithelium; Some thick mucus impeding the cilia beat in places; Mixed beat pattern with some slow, dyskinetic and static patches
Right atrial isomerism with a left-sided liver, right-sided stomach and right- sided polysplenia; DORV, with the pulmonary artery to the right and the aorta to the left; the aortic arch is rightward, and there is a common atrium; Both ventricles are small and there is a large inlet ventricular septal defect (VSD) and severe subpulmonary stenosis; Child has had a Glenn shunt performed
evidence.rdfs:label: Hartill Family A-II1

evidence.dc:description: Genetic complementation in dnaaf1-null zebrafish embryos demonstrated the rescue of normal heart looping with wild-type human DNAAF1, but not the p.Leu191Phe variant, supporting the argument that this DNAAF1 missense mutation is pathogenic.

This proband does not meet clinical standards for PCD diagnosis.  NM_178452.6(DNAAF1):c.571C>T (p.Leu191Phe) is a missense mutation that is predicted to be probably damaging by Polyphen-2. The p.Leu191Phe mutation in Family A falls within a region of leucine-rich repeat (LRR) domains in DNAAF1 and affects a highly conserved leucine residue. No CNV.

dc:description:
Primary Ciliary Dyskinesia (PCD) is a genetically heterogeneous group of disorders, usually beginning in early childhood, characterized by chronic cough, recurrent infections of the upper and lower respiratory tract, randomization of left/right body asymmetry, and subfertility (PMID: 32943623). The PCD phenotype results from structural and/or functional abnormalities of motile cilia and flagella. Ciliary motility is powered by a set of axoneme-specific dynein motor complexes. The cytoplasmic assembly of these large multiprotein complexes before their transport into cilia is assisted by dynein axonemal assembly factors (DNAAFs). Mutations in genes encoding DNAAFs result in the improper cytoplasmic preassembly of dynein chains, causing defects in both inner (IDA) and outer dynein arms (ODA) that can result in cilia immotility (PMID: 31624012). 

The *DNAAF1* (Dynein Axonemal Assembly Factor 1) gene was first reported in relation to PCD by Loges et al. and Duquesnoy et al. in 2009 (PMIDs: 19944400, 19944405).  Loges et al. identified *DNAAF1* (LRRC50) as a candidate disease gene through positional cloning in consanguineous PCD families with combined ODA and IDA defects. *DNAAF1* was specifically targeted for analysis because its orthologs in zebrafish and Chlamydomonas reinhardtii, *dnaaf1* and oda7 (PMIDs: 18385425, 17194703), had already been associated with cilia and flagella ultrastructural defects (ODA and IDA defects). Duquesnoy et al. followed a candidate gene approach that similarly targeted *DNAAF1* because of the defective ultrastructural phenotypes seen in C. reinhardtii oda7 mutant strains. Their PCD patients also exhibited an absence of both dynein arms. The specific disease entity, Primary Ciliary Dyskinesia 13 is an autosomal recessive disorder caused by homozygous or compound heterozygous mutations in the *DNAAF1* gene. Per criteria outlined by the ClinGen Lumping and Splitting Working Group, we found the molecular mechanism and autosomal recessive mode of inheritance to be consistent among unrelated patients, while the phenotypic variability among them appeared to represent a spectrum of disease rather than separate disease entities. Therefore, cases caused by inherited *DNAAF1* variants have been lumped into a single disease entity, Primary Ciliary Dyskinesia 13 (MONDO: 0013174, OMIM # 613193).

Evidence from 10 probands in 5 publications have been included in this curation representing 15 unique variants (1 missense, 3 nonsense, 9 frameshift, and 2 large intragenic deletions) (PMIDs: 19944400, 19944405, 29228333, 32502479, 30067075). The mechanism of pathogenicity in* DNAAF1* mutations appears to be biallelic loss of function. There is additional case-level variant evidence available in the literature, but its inclusion in this curation was not necessary to reach the maximum score for genetic evidence (12 points). Of note, in the process of curating genetic evidence for a gene-disease relationship between *DNAAF1* and PCD 13, it was observed that a subset of *DNAAF1* mutations can produce laterality defects in human patients without a complete PCD phenotype. These laterality defects can include complex heart defects and neural tube defects (PMIDs: 29228333, 34215651, 27543293).

The gene-disease association between *DNAAF1* and PCD 13 is supported by quantitative RT-PCR analysis that confirms that *DNAAF1 *(*LRRC50*) is highly expressed in human trachea, lung, and testis, all tissues containing multi-ciliated cells (PMID: 19944405). In situ hybridization analysis of whole mouse embryos shows Dnaaf1 (Lrrc50)  expression in the node (early gastrulation-stage embryos) and ciliated mouse respiratory epithelial cells (PMID: 1944400). This expression is consistent with a role for *DNAAF1* in ciliary axoneme assembly in motile ciliated cells of the left-right organizer and respiratory epithelial cells of mice and humans. Patients carrying *DNAAF1* mutations can develop severe respiratory symptoms, infertility, and laterality disorders, including in some cases complex congenital heart disease (PMID: 29228333). High-resolution immunofluorescence microscopy in control and *DNAAF1* (LRRC50)  mutant respiratory cells from one PCD patient showed a loss of the ODA heavy chains DNAH5 and DNAH9 and the ODA intermediate chain DNAI2 from the ciliary axonemes.  DNALI1, an IDA component, was also absent from all mutant ciliary axonemes and instead accumulated in the cytoplasm (PMID: 19944400). These data are consistent with *DNAAF1* assisting in the cytoplasmic assembly of axonemal dyneins.

The cytoplasmic folding and preassembly of dynein arm proteins into larger complexes takes place in a stepwise manner involving interactions with various DNAAFs, chaperones, and co-chaperones (PMID: 31817850). Co-immunoprecipitation assays from human cell culture extracts overexpressing *DNAAF1* confirm the interaction of* DNAAF1* with both endogenous RUVBL1 and RUVBL2 (PMID: 19944405). RUVBL1 and RUVBL2 are components of the R2TP/Prefoldin-like complex, an HSP90 co-chaperone complex involved in the assembly process of many molecular machines. While RUVBL1 and RUVBL2 have not been directly associated with PCD, they have been associated with dysfunction of motile cilia (PMIDs: 23858445, 29959317). The association of *DNAAF1* with an RUVBL1-RUVLB2 complex is consistent with *DNAAF1*â€™s involvement in axonemal dynein arm assembly. 

Three non-human models have been used to support the gene-disease relationship between *DNAAF1* and PCD 13. TbODA7 (*DNAAF1*) RNAi silencing in Trypanosoma brucei results in defective flagellar motility, the absence of ODAs, and the cytoplasmic accumulation of DNAI1 (ODA component),  all phenotypes consistent with a defect in dynein arm assembly (PMID: 19944405). Zebrafish embryos carrying a homozygous dnaaf1 mutation have immotile cilia, left-right polarity defects, a deficiency in pronephric fluid flow, and the development of pronephric cysts. Zebrafish mutants are missing outer dynein arms and in some cases have missing or misplaced inner dynein arms. These ultrastructural defects are consistent with a role for dnaaf1 in the preassembly of dynein arms in zebrafish. Mice carrying a homozygous loss of function Dnaaf1 mutation exhibit phenotypes consistent with those seen in PCD patients carrying *DNAAF1* mutations (PMID: 27261005). These phenotypes include severe respiratory infection and laterality defects.

In summary, there is definitive evidence supporting a gene-disease relationship between variants in *DNAAF1* and Primary Ciliary Dyskinesia 13. This has been repeatedly demonstrated in both research and clinical diagnostic settings, and has been upheld over time. This classification was approved by the ClinGen Motile Ciliopathy GCEP on March 9, 2023 (SOP Version 9).
